meanings.def: to cover something completely in paper or other material, for example when you are giving it as a present
examples: wrap something up He spent the evening wrapping up the Christmas presents.
wrap something individually wrapped chocolates
wrap something in something Each apple was wrapped in paper.
The cheese is cut and wrapped in plastic.
wrap something up in something fish and chips wrapped up in newspaper
Hip-hop and rap have come to dominate the record charts.
Teachers used to rap misbehaving pupils on the hand with a ruler.
We always wrap presents and leave them under the tree on Christmas Eve.
Cover the dough with plastic wrap and leave in the refrigerator.

meanings.def: to cover something/somebody in material, for example in order to protect it/them
examples: wrap A in B Wrap the meat in foil before you cook it.
wrap A up in B I wrapped the baby up in a blanket.
wrap yourself in something He tossed her a towel. ‘Wrap yourself in that.’
wrap yourself up in something She wrapped herself up in a long shawl.
wrap B round/around A I wrapped a blanket around the baby.
Christine was wrapped up in one of the blankets.
She wrapped the child carefully in a blanket.
A scarf was wrapped around his neck.
The nurse wrapped a bandage tightly around my ankle.
His arms were wrapped around her waist.
He wrapped his arms tightly around her waist.
He wrapped his hands around my neck and tried to strangle me.
She's got a towel wrapped around her head.

meanings.def: to cause a word or text to be carried over to a new line as the end of the previous line is reached by the writer; to be carried over in this way
examples: wrap something (around/round) How can I wrap the text around?
wrap (around/round) The text wraps around if it is too long to fit the screen.

meanings.def: to be so involved with somebody/something that you do not pay enough attention to other people or things
examples: They are completely wrapped up in their children.
She was so wrapped up in her work that she didn’t realize how late it was.

meanings.def: to persuade somebody to do anything that you want
examples: She has always been able to wrap her parents around her little finger.

idioms.def: to be so involved with somebody/something that you do not pay enough attention to other people or things
examples: They are completely wrapped up in their children.
She was so wrapped up in her work that she didn’t realize how late it was.

idioms.idiom: wrap/twist/wind somebody around your little finger
idioms.def: to persuade somebody to do anything that you want
examples: She has always been able to wrap her parents around her little finger.

related: twist/wrap/wind somebody around your little finger
wind/twist/wrap somebody around your little finger

meanings.def: a piece of cloth that a woman wears around her shoulders for decoration or to keep warm, or a loose piece of clothing worn over something else
examples: a cashmere wrap
a beach wrap

meanings.def: paper, plastic, etc. that is used for wrapping things in
examples: We stock a wide range of cards and gift wrap.
Use bubble wrap (= a sheet of plastic full of small bubbles of air) to pack things which might get broken.
Hip-hop and rap have come to dominate the record charts.
Teachers used to rap misbehaving pupils on the hand with a ruler.
We always wrap presents and leave them under the tree on Christmas Eve.
Cover the dough with plastic wrap and leave in the refrigerator.

meanings.def: used when making a film to say that filming has finished
examples: Cut! That's a wrap.

meanings.def: a type of sandwich made with a cold tortilla rolled around meat or vegetables
a special cover for any small electronic device that you can carry with you
examples: These are vinyl wraps that cover your entire phone with one thin sheath.

meanings.def: being kept secret until some time in the future
examples: Next year's collection is still being kept under wraps.

idioms.def: being kept secret until some time in the future
examples: Next year's collection is still being kept under wraps.
